Night-shooting practice, using ropes to maintain proper firing elevation.]] {{nihongo|'''''Tanegashima'''''|種子島}}, also {{nihongo|'''''hinawajū'''''|火縄銃}}, was a type of [[matchlock]] <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=XtmzFZS_SX0C&pg=PA257&dq=tanegashima+matchlock&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4h1dT7C-JtPLtgeUofSFDA&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=tanegashima%20matchlock&f=false ''East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History'', Authors Patricia Ebrey, Anne Walthall, James Palais, Publisher Cengage Learning, 2008, ISBN 0-547-00534-2, ISBN 978-0-547-00534-8 P257]</ref> configured [[arquebus]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6WQnNqhDNhAC&pg=PA4&dq=arquebus+tanegashima&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hF5dT7uzIYjNtgfiitWGDA&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=arquebus%20tanegashima&f=true ''Tanegashima: the arrival of Europe in Japan'', Authors Olof G. Lidin, Publisher NIAS Press, 2002, ISBN 87-91114-12-8, ISBN 978-87-91114-12-0 P.4]</ref> firearm introduced to [[Japan]] through the [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] in 1543.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6WQnNqhDNhAC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=true ''Tanegashima: the arrival of Europe in Japan'', Olof G. Lidin, Nordic Institute of Asian Studies, NIAS Press, 2002 P.1-14]</ref> Tanegashima were used by the [[samurai]] class and their foot soldiers ([[ashigaru]]) and within a few years the introduction of the tanegashima in battle changed the way war was fought in Japan forever.<ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4Ete0zPAnjwC&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=true |title= Giving up the gun: Japan's reversion to the sword, 1543-1879 |author= Noel Perrin, |publisher= David R Godine |year=1979 |accessdate=2011-09-22}}</ref>
==History==
===Origins=== The tanegashima seems to have been based on [[snap matchlock]]s that were produced in [[Portuguese India]], at the armory of [[Goa]] (a colony of Portugal [[Portuguese Conquest of Goa (1510)|since 1510]]).<ref>''The bewitched gun : the introduction of the firearm in the Far East by the Portuguese'', by Rainer Daehnhardt 1994 P.26</ref> The name ''tanegashima'' came from the Japanese island ([[Tanegashima]]) where a Chinese [[Junk (ship)|junk]] with Portuguese adventurers on board was driven to anchor by a storm in 1543. The lord of the Japanese island, Tanegashima Tokitaka (1528–1579), purchased two matchlock [[muskets]] from the Portuguese and put a swordsmith to work copying the matchlock barrel and firing mechanism. The smith (Yaita) did not have much of a problem with most of the gun but "drilling the barrel helically so that the screw (''bisen'' bolt) could be tightly inserted" was a major problem as this "technique did apparently not exist in Japan until this time." The Portuguese fixed their ship and left the island and only in the next year when a Portuguese blacksmith was brought back to Japan was the problem solved.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ySKq8vobam0C&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142&dq=drilling+the+barrel+helically+so+that+the+screw+could+be+tightly+inserted&source=bl&ots=x_vdGlSdQE&sig=hTG0u51FDSwZ_ENYMJ6tCQghHiE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_ecPT5eWHuKxiQKL-JmnDQ&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=drilling%20the%20barrel%20helically%20so%20that%20the%20screw%20could%20be%20tightly%20inserted&f=true ''Tanegashima: the arrival of Europe in Japan'', (Google eBook)Olof G. Lidin, Nordic Institute of Asian Studies, Taylor & Francis, 2002, p. 142]</ref> Within ten years of its introduction, over 300,000 tanegashima firearms were reported to have been manufactured.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=zPyswmGDBFkC&pg=PA30&dq=tanto+daisho&hl=en&ei=yE0tTvaULseRgQfMn7SECw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=12&ved=0CGkQ6AEwCw#v=onepage&q=tanto%20daisho&f=true ''The connoisseur's book of Japanese swords'', Author Kōkan Nagayama, Publisher Kodansha International, 1998, ISBN 4-7700-2071-6, ISBN 978-4-7700-2071-0 P.30]</ref>
===Sengoku period=== [[File:Ashigaru using shields (tate).jpg|thumb|''Ashigaru'' (foot soldiers) using matchlocks (''tanegashima'') from behind wooden pavises.]] Much of Japan was involved with internecine wars during the [[Sengoku period]] (1467-1603), as feudal lords vied for supremacy.<ref>Perrin p.9</ref> [[Matchlock]] guns were introduced about midway through the period, and after their introduction on the battlefield, were used extensively toward the end, and had a decisive role in warfare. In 1549, [[Oda Nobunaga]] ordered 500 guns to be made for his armies. The benefits of firearms were still relatively questionable, however, compared to other weapons. At the time, guns were still rather primitive and cumbersome. According to one estimate, in 16th century Japan, an archer could shoot 15 arrows in the time a gunner would take to load, charge, and fire a firearm.<ref name="Perrin p.15">Perrin p.15</ref> Effective range also was only 80 to 100 meters, and at that distance a bullet could easily bounce off armour. Matchlocks were vulnerable to humid or rainy conditions as the powder would become damp.<ref name="Perrin p.15"/> However, one advantage was that a firearm could be manned effectively by farmers or low-ranking [[ashigaru|infantry]].<ref name="Perrin p.25">Perrin p.25</ref>
The Japanese soon worked on various techniques to improve the effectiveness of their guns. They developed a serial firing technique to create a continuous rain of bullets on the enemy.<ref name="Perrin p.17">Perrin p.17</ref> They also developed bigger calibers to increase lethal power.<ref name="Perrin p.17"/> Protective boxes in [[lacquerware]] were invented to fit over the firing mechanism so it could still fire while it was raining,<ref>Perrin, p.18</ref> as were systems to accurately fire weapons at night by keeping fixed angles thanks to measured strings.<ref>Perrin, p.40</ref> [[File:EdoJapaneseArquebuse.jpg|thumb|left|Various antique tanegashima]] In 1563 the Amako of Izumo province won a victory over the Kikkawa with 33 of their adversaries wounded by tanegashima,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=YPkYMoO0ycIC&pg=PA147&dq=HIYA+fire+arrow&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IGoyT6LMEoXhtgeU7oSbBw&sqi=2&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=HIYA%20fire%20arrow&f=true ''War and state building in medieval Japan'', Authors John A. Ferejohn, Frances McCall Rosenbluth, Frances Rosenbluth, Editors John A. Ferejohn, Frances McCall Rosenbluth, Frances Rosenbluth, Edition illustrated, Publisher Stanford University Press, 2010, ISBN 0-8047-6370-4, ISBN 978-0-8047-6370-7 P.147]</ref> as a result, in the year 1567 [[Takeda Shingen]] announced that, "Hereafter, the guns will be the most important arms, therefore decrease the number of spears per unit, and have your most capable men carry guns".<ref>Perrin, p.17</ref> [[Oda Nobunaga]] used tanegashima in the [[Battle of Anegawa]] (1570), and again against the powerful Takeda clan in the [[Battle of Nagashino]] (1575), 3,000 gunners helped win the battle, firing by volleys of a thousand at a time. They were concealed across a river and used breastworks to effectively stop enemy infantry and cavalry charges while being protected.<ref>Perrin p.19-20</ref> The defeat of the powerful Takeda clan brought about permanent changes in battle tactics.
Japan became so enthusiastic about the new weapons that it possibly overtook every European country in absolute numbers produced.<ref name="Perrin p.25"/> Japan also used the guns in the [[Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598)|Japanese invasion of Korea]] in 1592, in which about a quarter of the invasion force of 160,000 were gunners.<ref>Perrin p.27</ref> They were extremely successful at first and managed to capture [[Seoul]] just 18 days after their landing at [[Pusan]].<ref>Perrin p.28</ref>
===Edo period=== [[File:Bronze barreled Japanese matchlock pistol.jpg|thumb|Antique Japanese (samurai) tanegashima (matchlock) pistol]] The internal war for control of Japan was won by [[Tokugawa Ieyasu]] who defeated his rivals at the Battle of Sekigahara in October 1600. Three years later, he established the [[Tokugawa Shogunate]], a powerful entity that would maintain peace, stability, and prosperity in Japan for the following 250 years. This is known as the [[Edo period]] (1603-1868). From the mid 17th century, Japan decided to close itself to interaction with the West as well as its close neighbors of China and Korea through its policy of [[Sakoku]]. Contrary to popular belief, this did not lead to Japan "giving up the gun." If anything, the gun was used less frequently because the Edo Period did not have many large-scale conflicts in which a gun would be of use. Often the sword was simply the more practical weapon in the average small-scale conflicts. It should also be noted that isolation did not decrease the production of guns in Japan—on the contrary, there is evidence of around 200 gunsmiths in Japan by the end of the Edo Period.<ref>Samurai Archives Podcast EP05 [http://www.samuraipodcast.com/ep05-the-myth-of-samurai-giving-up-the-gun "The Myth of Samurai Giving Up the Gun"]. Retrieved August 13, 2013.</ref> But the social life of firearms had changed: as the historian David L. Howell has argued, for many in Japanese society, the gun had become less a weapon than a farm implement for scaring off animals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Howell|first=David L.|title=The Social Life of Firearms in Tokugawa Japan|journal=Japanese Studies|date=1 May 2009|volume=29|issue=1|pages=65–80|doi=10.1080/10371390902780530|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10371390902780530?journalCode=cjst20#preview|accessdate=15 January 2012}}</ref> With no external enemies for over 200 years, tanegashima were mainly used by samurai for hunting and target practice, the majority were relegated to the arms store houses of the various feudal lords ([[daimyo]]). [[File:Himeji Oshiro Matsuri August09 007.jpg|thumb|left|Modern tanegashima gun troop in Japan]] The arrival in Japan of the United States Navy led by [[Matthew C. Perry|Commodore Perry]] in 1854 started a period of re-armament. The tanegashima was an antiquated weapon by the 1800s and various samurai factions acquired advanced firearms including the [[minié rifle]], breech-loading and repeating rifles. The samurai era ended in 1868 with the [[Meiji era]], the Japanese turned to a national conscription army with modern weapons and uniforms. The last use of samurai armour and traditional weapons including tanegashima in Japan was during the [[Satsuma rebellion]] (1877), when the Meiji government's newly established [[Imperial Japanese Army]] put an end to the last samurai and their resistance to modernization.
===Modern use=== Today tanegashima are readily available from sellers of antique firearms and dealers of samurai antiques both in Japan and the West. Modern tanegashima gun troops in Japan re-enact the use of tanegashima in battle and black powder enthusiasts use tanegashima for target practice.
